String.Source: Welcome to The Sims™ 4 Create a Pet! This lesson will give you a quick overview of the features available in Create a Pet. Making a Pet is very similar to making a human Sim - just a touch furrier. For a deeper dive, click on any of the more detailed Create a Pet lessons from the menu.
String.Dest: Welcome to The Sims™ 4 Create a Pet! This lesson will give you a quick overview of the features available in Create a Pet. Making a Pet is very similar to making a human Sim - just a touch furrier. For a deeper dive, click on any of the more detailed Create a Pet lessons from the menu.

String.Source: Create a Sim starts you off with a premade human Sim. To add a cat or a dog to the household, click the Add Sim button to the right of your human Sim's skewer thumbnail.
String.Dest: Create a Sim starts you off with a premade human Sim. To add a cat or a dog to the household, click the Add Sim button to the right of your human Sim's skewer thumbnail.

String.Source: Choose the specific breed you had in mind from the Breed catalog or play around with making a Mix Breed! Or just click away at the Randomize button in the bottom of the screen to see what kind of pets come your way.
String.Dest: Choose the specific breed you had in mind from the Breed catalog or play around with making a Mix Breed! Or just click away at the Randomize button in the bottom of the screen to see what kind of pets come your way.

String.Source: Now for the fun part: start customizing! Just like human Sims, you can directly modify the shape of your pet's body and face by clicking and dragging on the area you want to shape. Change your pet's fur length, ears, or coat markings from the options offered in the arc menu's catalogs. Did we mention you can also Paint on your pet or dress them in cute little outfits? Click on the detailed lessons in the menu for more info!
String.Dest: Now for the fun part: start customizing! Just like human Sims, you can directly modify the shape of your pet's body and face by clicking and dragging on the area you want to shape. Change your pet's fur length, ears, or coat markings from the options offered in the arc menu's catalogs. Did we mention you can also Paint on your pet or dress them in cute little outfits? Click on the detailed lessons in the menu for more info!

String.Source: Painting is set to paint on both sides of the pet by default, but if you want to go for an asymmetrical look, simply click the mirror paint button. If you want to cover your entire pet with a certain color, use the Fill Color tool.
String.Dest: Painting is set to paint on both sides of the pet by default, but if you want to go for an asymmetrical look, simply click the mirror paint button. If you want to cover your entire pet with a certain color, use the Fill Color tool.

String.Source: Paint Mode can be accessed from a few places: click on the bottom arc menu button from the face or body arc menu, or click on the Paint Mode button at the top of the Coat Color / Pattern catalog.
String.Dest: Paint Mode can be accessed from a few places: click on the bottom arc menu button from the face or body arc menu, or click on the Paint Mode button at the top of the Coat Color / Pattern catalog.

String.Source: Start Painting! Just like you can directly push and pull to change the shape of your pet, you can use your mouse cursor as a paint brush to create a hairy masterpiece. Choose from the available color swatches or fine-tune your own color with the color wheel. Click the square to the left of the color wheel to adjust the hue/saturation/brightness values manually.
String.Dest: Start Painting! Just like you can directly push and pull to change the shape of your pet, you can use your mouse cursor as a paint brush to create a hairy masterpiece. Choose from the available color swatches or fine-tune your own color with the color wheel. Click the square to the left of the color wheel to adjust the hue/saturation/brightness values manually.

String.Source: Choose from a variety of paintbrush shapes and use the Size and Rotation sliders for the exact look you want. Or go a little crazy and play with the Stamps from the Stamps tab. Who said dogs can't be covered in plumbobs?
String.Dest: Choose from a variety of paintbrush shapes and use the Size and Rotation sliders for the exact look you want. Or go a little crazy and play with the Stamps from the Stamps tab. Who said dogs can't be covered in plumbobs?

String.Source: Trying to reach a specific spot? Use the Pose buttons at the top of the screen to access your pet's belly or to get a better look at the top of their head. You can also paint your Pet's nose, inner ears, or paws by clicking the Detail Paint Mode button when you're zoomed in.
String.Dest: Trying to reach a specific spot? Use the Pose buttons at the top of the screen to access your pet's belly or to get a better look at the top of their head. You can also paint your Pet's nose, inner ears, or paws by clicking the Detail Paint Mode button when you're zoomed in.

String.Source: Use the Stencils tab to paint within artist-crafted marking patterns with precision. Play around with the Fill Color tool or paint over the stencil area with multiple colors to get some crazy combinations!
String.Dest: Use the Stencils tab to paint within artist-crafted marking patterns with precision. Play around with the Fill Color tool or paint over the stencil area with multiple colors to get some crazy combinations!

String.Source: When you're done painting, go ahead and click the Back button in the upper left of the paint panel. Or click the Clear All button to start from scratch.
String.Dest: When you're done painting, go ahead and click the Back button in the upper left of the paint panel. Or click the Clear All button to start from scratch.

String.Source: In what began as a stirring series of indictments and "hot takes" in the local newspaper, the Op-Ed Column inspired an architectural movement with its long, firm, unwavering line of commentary. It will not move, and instead, will prop up any local home with its intense view points.
String.Dest: In what began as a stirring series of indictments and "hot takes" in the local newspaper, the Op-Ed Column inspired an architectural movement with its long, firm, unwavering line of commentary. It will not move, and instead, will prop up any local home with its intense view points.

String.Source: We here at Carpeted Conifers pride ourselves in selling only the finest cat trees, chopped fresh from the carpeted jungles of Catalonia, and to be honest, we' tried something new here. By waiting until the heart of winter when the cat trees had shed their fluffy, plush carpeting, we ended up with this sleek and beautiful feline funhouse.

String.Source: Need to establish relations with your fractious feline? Having trouble keeping your bored pet entertained? Look no further than the Cat Dazzler! This simple mechanism guarantees HOURS of entertainment for your barely domesticated carnivore. All you do is shake this in front of your cat and watch it attempt to slaughter the Dazzler instead of your family. Surviving ownership of a cat has never been easier.

String.Source: Pigeons can be found all over the world. Often called the rats of the bird kingdom, the pigeon has been unfairly maligned. It is quite majestic compared to many nonflying creatures.
String.Dest: Pigeons can be found all over the world. Often called the rats of the bird kingdom, the pigeon has been unfairly maligned. It is quite majestic compared to many nonflying creatures.

String.Dest: This somewhat elegant bird roams coastal lands but are sometimes found inland. Its activities include fighting over trash, stealing food, and making dock workers angry.

String.Dest: This ebony plume belongs to the crafty crow. Many chase these fine avians from their homes mistaking them for thieves. They are mistaken. Crows only take what they need, and never more.

String.Dest: Finches are very attractive birds with their variety of colors and patterns. Many covet these as pets despite the finch's utter distaste of humanity. They are also nervous wrecks.

String.Dest: The colorful cardinal loves its seeds and showing off its impressive coat. While they make excellent neighbors, they are not well known for their baseball skills.

String.Dest: The Blue Jay is most known for its magnificent cerulean plumage. Less known is its intelligence and propensity to be a family bird. Yet, their baseball skill remains questionable, worse than cardinals even.

String.Source: A series of paintings depicting the various key Brindletonians, all with some connection to Deadgrass Isle and the Tragedy of the Saint Bernard. Legend has it, in the earliest days of Brindleton Bay’s settlement, the citizens had no pets at all. The settlers had nothing to keep them entertained but tales of a plasma-sucking phantom that came in the night. One night, disaster struck. The Saint Bernard, a formidable ship to say the least, crashed headlong into the isle offshore and was lost to the waves. Mysteriously, lifeboats full of cats and dogs made their way to the shore, but there were no humans to be found. It is said that the Captain's ghost now roams the city at night, checking to make sure the ancestors of the pets that survived were given good homes, and that those lost in the crash are comfortably living out their nine afterlives on Deadgrass Isle.
String.Dest: A series of paintings depicting the various key Brindletonians, all with some connection to Deadgrass Isle and the Tragedy of the Saint Bernard. Legend has it, in the earliest days of Brindleton Bay’s settlement, the citizens had no pets at all. The settlers had nothing to keep them entertained but tales of a plasma-sucking phantom that came in the night. One night, disaster struck. The Saint Bernard, a formidable ship to say the least, crashed headlong into the isle offshore and was lost to the waves. Mysteriously, lifeboats full of cats and dogs made their way to the shore, but there were no humans to be found. It is said that the Captain's ghost now roams the city at night, checking to make sure the ancestors of the pets that survived were given good homes, and that those lost in the crash are comfortably living out their nine afterlives on Deadgrass Isle.

String.Source: The Tragedy of the Saint Bernard, and Other Tales from the Isle
String.Dest: The Tragedy of the Saint Bernard, and Other Tales from the Isle

String.Source: A series of paintings depicting Brindeton Bay’s earliest days. Before their pets crashed ashore, Brindletonians had an enormous amount of free time that they spent tending to the fields and perfecting the covered bridge that overlooks Sable Square. Following the arrival of cats and dogs during the Tragedy of the Saint Bernard, the town's obsession with their new four-legged friends would lead them to erect huge monuments to cats and dogs throughout the square, and kick start a burgeoning fishing and pet food industry. Today, the town is thriving, with feline and canine influences woven directly into the community's DNA. The locals have even elected a cat as their mayor!
String.Dest: A series of paintings depicting Brindeton Bay’s earliest days. Before their pets crashed ashore, Brindletonians had an enormous amount of free time that they spent tending to the fields and perfecting the covered bridge that overlooks Sable Square. Following the arrival of cats and dogs during the Tragedy of the Saint Bernard, the town's obsession with their new four-legged friends would lead them to erect huge monuments to cats and dogs throughout the square, and kick start a burgeoning fishing and pet food industry. Today, the town is thriving, with feline and canine influences woven directly into the community's DNA. The locals have even elected a cat as their mayor!

String.Source: The people have bespoken, and we understand the problem: You want a so-classic-it’s-cool dining room chair, but you’re nervous about the origin of the cushions. Where were they sourced from? Was anyone hurt procuring the materials? How many designers lost their lives fighting over the perfect pattern? Totally understandable. Worry no longer. Seriously, please calm down. This old-is-new-again-because-we-say-so chair is accompanied by only the most conflict-averse of cushions- most of them haven’t even heard someone raise their voice before!

String.Source: Unsatisfied with the ottoman in your life? Maybe you’ve just been let down one too many times by an unsavory ottoman, or maybe you’ve just never met the right one. Say hello to the ottoman of your dreams: An ottoman that’ll always notice your new hairstyle, and never argue against your pick for movie night. An ottoman that is rarely late and always texts you right back. An ottoman that looks just as great in red as it does in blue, and is comfortable enough with its ottomasculinity to do so. An ottoman that would absolutely love to meet your parents, and they’ll love to meet it too. You deserve a real ottoman, so what’re you waiting for?

String.Source: Nothing says coastal comfort quite like this massive plush armchair. “Coastal comfort,” it’ll whisper as you sink into its luxurious embrace. “What was that?” you’ll ask aloud, feeling foolish as you realize you’re alone in the room. “Coastal. Comfort.” the chair will repeat, louder this time. Honestly, it’s rather unsettling, so we covered it up with a cozy little blanket. Enjoy!

String.Source: Some claim that sitting in an armless chair is as hazardous as skydiving without a parachute. “There’s nothing holding you in! What if you slip!? It’s such a long way down!” Rest assured that the Completely Armless canvass covered chair is field tested and certified perfectly safe. Covering the surrounding floor with a soft batting or bubble wrap is recommended. We also suggest children and elders wear protective headgear when sitting in the chair. In fact, perhaps you should wear a mouth guard while enjoying the Completely Armless chair. Make sure to maintain a firm, upright position to avoid slipping to your doom.
String.Dest: Some claim that sitting in an armless chair is as hazardous as skydiving without a parachute. “There’s nothing holding you in! What if you slip!? String.Source: Add some eye candy to your front yard or entryway with this lovely painted wood bench with ornate wrought iron details. We’ve found it works perfectly in the park for a moment to sit and recharge during a game of fetch. Or if you’re the type who just likes to come to the dog park and watch. Why do you do that? Maybe it’s time you adopt one. But perhaps you don’t feel ready for the responsibility? Maybe you don’t identify as a “dog person” and don’t know if now is the time to make that leap? Why sign up for all of that when I can just admire everyone else’s dogs from afar? In any case, this bench is for you.

String.Source: When a local elder attempted to restore this priceless collection of landscape paintings, things didn’t exactly go as planned. Rather than revealing her disastrous finger-paintings, she opted instead to ditch the art entirely and fill the frames with single-pane glass.
String.Dest: When a local elder attempted to restore this priceless collection of landscape paintings, things didn’t exactly go as planned. Rather than revealing her disastrous finger-paintings, she opted instead to ditch the art entirely and fill the frames with single-pane glass.

String.Source: Local designer Boozer Pawson believes there is no truer art than a good dog, and that a good dog can be found in practically anything. “Take for instance, these three windows,” Boozer once exclaimed. “I can see three good dogs sitting in them right now!” It’s unclear whether he was referencing the beagle, Australian shepherd, and Portuguese water dog sitting on the opposite side of the glass, or going for some sort of artistic metaphor, but our marketing team preferred the latter.
String.Dest: Local designer Boozer Pawson believes there is no truer art than a good dog, and that a good dog can be found in practically anything. “Take for instance, these three windows,” Boozer once exclaimed. “I can see three good dogs sitting in them right now!” It’s unclear whether he was referencing the beagle, Australian shepherd, and Portuguese water dog sitting on the opposite side of the glass, or going for some sort of artistic metaphor, but our marketing team preferred the latter.

String.Source: With so many individual panes, this window arrangement is sure to make any room lit. All your friends will be saying, “Wow, this is so lit. Like, literally. So lit.”
String.Dest: With so many individual panes, this window arrangement is sure to make any room lit. All your friends will be saying, “Wow, this is so lit. Like, literally. So lit.”

String.Source: With gorgeous porches, a backyard swimming pool, and a phenomenal view of the Brindleton Light, this Dutch colonial is one of the most admired properties in the Bay.
String.Dest: With gorgeous porches, a backyard swimming pool, and a phenomenal view of the Brindleton Light, this Dutch colonial is one of the most admired properties in the Bay.

String.Source: While Supriya loves her full-time job as a stay-at-home mom, it’s been getting harder and harder to suppress her dreams of being a full-fledged veterinarian. Especially now that the owner of the Brindleton Pawspital is looking to sell the business. Her husband Justin has always been supportive, and keeps offering to take a break from work so she can follow her dream. But can Supriya really trust him to keep the peace at home between Blue and Bartholomew? Not to mention Pierce and Evie too!
String.Dest: While Supriya loves her full-time job as a stay-at-home mom, it’s been getting harder and harder to suppress her dreams of being a full-fledged veterinarian. Especially now that the owner of the Brindleton Pawspital is looking to sell the business. Her husband Justin has always been supportive, and keeps offering to take a break from work so she can follow her dream. But can Supriya really trust him to keep the peace at home between Blue and Bartholomew? Not to mention Pierce and Evie too!

String.Source: Easy access to the creek below makes this property a must-own for nature-loving homebuilders. You don’t want to wait for your life to be over- purchase this property and get building!
String.Dest: Easy access to the creek below makes this property a must-own for nature-loving homebuilders. You don’t want to wait for your life to be over- purchase this property and get building!

String.Source: Tucked away between the expensive mansions of Cavalier Cove is this humble little cottage. Nothing says “beach access” like living right on the beach!
String.Dest: Tucked away between the expensive mansions of Cavalier Cove is this humble little cottage. Nothing says “beach access” like living right on the beach!

String.Source: The largest property in Brindleton Bay- and with its very own private beach - Hound’s Head has housed a variety of rich and powerful pets (and their owners) through the ages.
String.Dest: The largest property in Brindleton Bay- and with its very own private beach - Hound’s Head has housed a variety of rich and powerful pets (and their owners) through the ages.

String.Source: The Hindquarter Hideaway may be the furthest property from the water’s edge, but the small fishing pond nearby more than makes up for it.
String.Dest: The Hindquarter Hideaway may be the furthest property from the water’s edge, but the small fishing pond nearby more than makes up for it.

String.Source: Once a part of the pet food cannery next door, this warehouse has since been converted into a stellar two-story home.
String.Dest: Once a part of the pet food cannery next door, this warehouse has since been converted into a stellar two-story home.

String.Source: From sailors to spaniels to Scottish folds, the Salty Paws Saloon is a neighborhood staple and a favorite hangout spot for locals, human or otherwise.
String.Dest: From sailors to spaniels to Scottish folds, the Salty Paws Saloon is a neighborhood staple and a favorite hangout spot for locals, human or otherwise.

String.Source: Previously an exclusive yacht club for only the richest citizens of Brindleton Bay, a recent decree by Mayor Whiskers opened up this pool and wedding locale for public use.
String.Dest: Previously an exclusive yacht club for only the richest citizens of Brindleton Bay, a recent decree by Mayor Whiskers opened up this pool and wedding locale for public use.

String.Source: Smackdab in the middle of Whiskerman’s Wharf, this modest home is absolutely perfect for someone who can’t get enough of the frenetic felines that hang out by the docks.
String.Dest: Smackdab in the middle of Whiskerman’s Wharf, this modest home is absolutely perfect for someone who can’t get enough of the frenetic felines that hang out by the docks.

String.Source: Cats in the neighborhood know where to go for a good meal. Catarina’s always had a soft spot for animals, and the cats she lives with have the best home a cat could ask for. Sometimes Catarina asks herself if there’s something more to life than cats… usually right before she adopts another stray.
String.Dest: Cats in the neighborhood know where to go for a good meal. Catarina’s always had a soft spot for animals, and the cats she lives with have the best home a cat could ask for. Sometimes Catarina asks herself if there’s something more to life than cats… usually right before she adopts another stray.

String.Source: Far from the bustle of the dockyards, this secluded lot still has plenty of that harbor charm (and a beautiful view to boot!)
String.Dest: Far from the bustle of the dockyards, this secluded lot still has plenty of that harbor charm (and a beautiful view to boot!)

String.Source: After almost two centuries as the lighthouse keeper’s private home, this property was converted into a museum chronicling the Bay’s interesting maritime history when a new automated system was installed in the Brindleton Light.
String.Dest: After almost two centuries as the lighthouse keeper’s private home, this property was converted into a museum chronicling the Bay’s interesting maritime history when a new automated system was installed in the Brindleton Light.

String.Source: A series of renovations have restored this mid-century house to its former glory. All houses are good houses, but this one is especially good.
String.Dest: A series of renovations have restored this mid-century house to its former glory. All houses are good houses, but this one is especially good.

String.Source: A charmingly classic home steps away from the heart of Sable Square, Domus Familiaris is the ideal abode for a new family moving to the Bay.
String.Dest: A charmingly classic home steps away from the heart of Sable Square, Domus Familiaris is the ideal abode for a new family moving to the Bay.

String.Source: Life in their new home seems to agree with newlyweds Brent and Brant. The small-town bustle inspires Brent’s painting, and Brant loves to explore the Bay's beautiful neighborhoods. But will they ever agree on who gets to take their beloved Rosie with them?
String.Dest: Life in their new home seems to agree with newlyweds Brent and Brant. The small-town bustle inspires Brent’s painting, and Brant loves to explore the Bay's beautiful neighborhoods. But will they ever agree on who gets to take their beloved Rosie with them?

String.Source: Central and affordable, this property is just waiting to be developed.
String.Dest: Central and affordable, this property is just waiting to be developed.

String.Source: This state-of-the-art facility offers the very best in pet care for your sick barker or meower. Rumor has it the owner is preparing for retirement soon and is interested in selling the place to a young aspiring vet.

String.Source: All a dog and {M1.his}{F1.her} human need is a simple visit to the Town Square.
String.Dest: All a dog and {M1.his}{F1.her} human need is a simple visit to the Town Square.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} would like to help every crying child in the world, but {M0.he}{F0.she} has {M0.his}{F0.her} own priorities. {M0.He}{F0.She} pulls {1.SimFirstName} back and keeps walking.
{1.SimFirstName} seems a little miffed at first and takes {M1.his}{F1.her} time peeing on a fire hydrant. They finish their perfectly square walk, in perfect time. {0.SimFirstName} pets {1.SimFirstName} between the ears, and {1.SimFirstName} returns it with a sloppy kiss. It really was a good walk.
String.Dest:
{0.SimFirstName} would like to help every crying child in the world, but {M0.he}{F0.she} has {M0.his}{F0.her} own priorities. {M0.He}{F0.She} pulls {1.SimFirstName} back and keeps walking.
{1.SimFirstName} seems a little miffed at first and takes {M1.his}{F1.her} time peeing on a fire hydrant. They finish their perfectly square walk, in perfect time. {0.SimFirstName} pets {1.SimFirstName} between the ears, and {1.SimFirstName} returns it with a sloppy kiss. It really was a good walk.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} would have to be a monster to ignore a crying child. {1.SimFirstName} leads them in a diagonal jaywalk across the street.
The toddler is incoherent. There isn't much {0.SimFirstName} can do, so {M0.he}{F0.she} tries to entertain the tot by having {1.SimFirstName} perform a trick. The toddler's distraught parent comes by soon after, at which point the tears are gone and the toddler is cheering in delight at The Fantastic {1.SimFirstName}'s Death-Defying Sit.
String.Dest:
{0.SimFirstName} would have to be a monster to ignore a crying child. {1.SimFirstName} leads them in a diagonal jaywalk across the street.
The toddler is incoherent. There isn't much {0.SimFirstName} can do, so {M0.he}{F0.she} tries to entertain the tot by having {1.SimFirstName} perform a trick. The toddler's distraught parent comes by soon after, at which point the tears are gone and the toddler is cheering in delight at The Fantastic {1.SimFirstName}'s Death-Defying Sit.

String.Source:
Everything is going just as expected. {0.SimFirstName} takes the third left on the last turn towards home. Maybe {M0.he}{F0.she} can finally achieve {M0.his}{F0.her} dream: a square walk around the Town Square.
{1.SimName} does not share his vision. Ahead, a toddler is crying on a bench and {1.SimName} tugs {M1.his}{F1.her} leash towards him.
String.Dest:
Everything is going just as expected. {0.SimFirstName} takes the third left on the last turn towards home. Maybe {M0.he}{F0.she} can finally achieve {M0.his}{F0.her} dream: a square walk around the Town Square.
{1.SimName} does not share his vision. Ahead, a toddler is crying on a bench and {1.SimName} tugs {M1.his}{F1.her} leash towards him.

String.Source:
Just in time, {0.SimFirstName} contains {1.SimFirstName}'s animal instinct to launch into mud. With {1.SimFirstName} still suspended by the end of the leash, {0.SimFirstName} takes a second to look over and see what has the dog so intrigued.
Something is there, hidden under the mud. {0.SimFirstName} slacks the leash, allowing {1.SimFirstName} to pick it up. {1.SimFirstName}'s head is held high as {M1.he}{F1.she} proudly walks {M1.his}{F1.her} treasure home.
String.Dest:
Just in time, {0.SimFirstName} contains {1.SimFirstName}'s animal instinct to launch into mud. With {1.SimFirstName} still suspended by the end of the leash, {0.SimFirstName} takes a second to look over and see what has the dog so intrigued.
Something is there, hidden under the mud. {0.SimFirstName} slacks the leash, allowing {1.SimFirstName} to pick it up. {1.SimFirstName}'s head is held high as {M1.he}{F1.she} proudly walks {M1.his}{F1.her} treasure home.

String.Source:
It was done in an instant. Forced forward by the sheer will for adventure, both dog and human catapult into mud. {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} finish their walk home, absolutely filthy.
Even so, it's hard to stay mad. {1.SimFirstName} might smell like garbage, but {M1.his}{F1.her} tail is wagging. {0.SimFirstName}'s happy {M1.he}{F1.she} had a good time.
String.Dest:

Just {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName}, out for a walk. {0.SimFirstName} appreciates time with {M0.his}{F0.her} pet, as it feels like sometimes {M0.he}{F0.she} obeys a compulsive need to socialize with other people. It's nice to have a moment alone.

String.Source:
The two enter the Brindleton Light Information Center and Gift Shop, where an elderly white-haired man is selling postcards.
He sees them and brightens up. "The top of the lighthouse is always open for the best views of the bay, but I'm about to go on break. Next time, I'll take you through and teach you some interesting history!"
With that, he shoos them out where {0.SimFirstName} looks up at the lighthouse once more before heading home.

With that, he shoos them out where {0.SimFirstName} looks up at the lighthouse once more before heading home.

String.Source:
As tempting as it would be to explore the lighthouse on their own, {0.SimFirstName} encourages {1.SimFirstName} to stay on this side of the door.
The two browse the shop for a bit and learn some interesting facts - that the lighthouse has only been dark for 24 hours since it first opened and that the older stairways inside the lighthouse are closed but still considered perfectly safe to climb.
As {0.SimFirstName} looks over a poster with the historical timeline of the lighthouse, {1.SimFirstName} scurries back to {M0.him}{F0.her} in a rush, eyeing the door marked Private nervously. {0.SimFirstName} looks up and sees...what? A white flash going by? A...ghost? Impossible!
{0.SimFirstName} promises {1.SimFirstName} they'll return next time to follow up.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} tries the door handle, which turns easily, and the two tumble through. After their eyes adjust to the darkness, they see a small storage area with boxes stacked on boxes.
At the end of the room is a rickety-looking roped-off stairway. {0.SimFirstName} notices a white tablecloth in a nearby storage box and slips it on. "Look, I'm a ghost!" {M0.he}{F0.she} shouts, as {1.SimFirstName} starts barking at something behind {0.SimFirstName}.
{0.SimFirstName} can't see much with the tablecloth on {M0.his}{F0.her} head. {M0.He}{F0.She} pulls it off to see a small...apparition dart up the stairs. {1.SimFirstName} howls but the chase is already lost. "Probably just a raccoon," {0.SimFirstName} says, and pats {1.SimFirstName} on the head, promising to return to the lighthouse.

String.Source:
They've barely rounded the block before {1.SimFirstName} takes off for the lighthouse. They step into the gift shop but the old man isn't there.
The two wait for a moment, but the stillness of the shop starts to give {0.SimFirstName} goosebumps. {1.SimFirstName} paws at a door off the back marked Private. Should the pair explore on their own?

The two wait for a moment, but the stillness of the shop starts to give {0.SimFirstName} goosebumps. {1.SimFirstName} paws at a door off the back marked Private. Should the pair explore on their own?

String.Source:
They walk in and the old man says, "ready to learn a little something?" As he begins the tour, {0.SimFirstName} interjects with a question about the supposed ghost that haunts the lighthouse.
"Oh, that old story," the man mutters, as if he can't be bothered. "Some say it's the old pooch who belonged Mr. Friendly - the last person to run the lighthouse. Hanging around, unfinished business or some nonsense."
"Mr. Friendly was let go when he let the lighthouse go dark, causing a shipwreck. That damn dog wouldn't leave, though, and died right in the lighthouse office." As the tour ends, the man sends {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} on their way, though the story of Mr. Friendly's dog makes their hairs all stand a bit straighter.

As the tour ends, the man sends {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} on their way, though the story of Mr. Friendly's dog makes their hairs all stand a bit straighter.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} wait until the man's gone, then swoop into the shop and hurtle through the door they're not supposed to hurtle through. The two head up the rickety steps and find a door simply marked Office.
There's no lock and the door opens creakily. {1.SimFirstName} nudges {0.SimFirstName} toward the far wall, where on a bulletin board are pinned various articles about the Brindleton Wreck and a few pictures of a friendly-looking man and his dog in front of the lighthouse.
{0.SimFirstName}'s reading an article intently when {1.SimFirstName} nearly bowls {M0.him}{F0.her} over. That's when {0.SimFirstName} hears someone opening the door. The two hide in the shadows of the room; just in time, as the old man has returned and clatters into the room.
The old man moving quickly and sounds angry, muttering something about a change in the shipping schedule and storms out. {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} wait a good ten minutes before leaving themselves, nervous and suspicious.

String.Source:
As {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} get to the lighthouse, they notice the old man once again working diligently.
They remember him mentioning that behind-the-scenes tour, but they also remember the staircase and the ghost. Or not - {0.SimFirstName}'s convinced {M0.himself}{F0.herself} there's a sensible explanation for all of this.
Should they take the man up on his offer to show them around the lighthouse or wait for a moment when they can sneak into the lighthouse undisturbed?

They remember him mentioning that behind-the-scenes tour, but they also remember the staircase and the ghost. Or not - {0.SimFirstName}'s convinced {M0.himself}{F0.herself} there's a sensible explanation for all of this.
Should they take the man up on his offer to show them around the lighthouse or wait for a moment when they can sneak into the lighthouse undisturbed?

String.Source:
"Oh, that old story," the man mutters, as if he can't be bothered. "Some say the pooch belonged to Mr. Friendly, who used run this lighthouse. That it still haunts it today! Unfinished business or some nonsense. But I've never seen nor heard it for as long as I've been here." By his slow movements, {0.SimFirstName} assumes that's quite some time.
"You know what it is," the old man says. "I bet it's just some young rascals getting into our tablecloths we keep in storage and making out like they're a spirit."
The tour ends as abruptly as it began. As they head home, {0.SimFirstName} assures {1.SimFirstName} they'll return and figure out this whole ghost thing one way or another. {0.SimFirstName} looks back and a shiver goes down {M0.his}{F0.her} spine as {M0.he}{F0.she} sees the old man staring right at them from the darkened gift shop.

The tour ends as abruptly as it began. As they head home, {0.SimFirstName} assures {1.SimFirstName} they'll return and figure out this whole ghost thing one way or another. {0.SimFirstName} looks back and a shiver goes down {M0.his}{F0.her} spine as {M0.he}{F0.she} sees the old man staring right at them from the darkened gift shop.

String.Source:
"It was a sad day, indeed," the old man replies. The man running the lighthouse at the time - one Mr. Friendly - had taken his dog to the vet, forgetting that a cargo ship was docking that night.
The lighthouse light was left off and the ship wrecked. While there were no deaths, a large crab shipment was lost and along with it, the lucrative contract Brindleton Bay had established with the crabbing company.
The man continues, "anyway, Mr. Friendly was sacked but his damn dog wouldn't leave the lighthouse and died soon after right in the office."
The tour ends soon after and {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} vow to return, though the story of the dog who died in the lighthouse haunts them on their way home.

String.Source:
As {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} get to the lighthouse, they notice the old man once again working diligently at the gift shop. He launches into a history of the lighthouse before they've said two words and continues talking as he guides them upstairs to the top of the lighthouse.
It's interesting, but a bit dry. Dates and names and construction materials all start to run together, and {1.SimFirstName} is starting to get restless. {0.SimFirstName} wants to ask about the ghost, but it also feels like a bit of a silly question.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} spreads the glue on the floor of the lookout behind the old man, who is busy watching for something out at sea. It dries quickly.
{1.SimFirstName} nuzzles the ghostly dog, who drifts through the old man. The sensation surprises him and he yelps and stumbles backwards. Right into the glue! He sticks and falls. {1.SimFirstName} growls at him and takes the man's hair in his mouth as {0.SimFirstName} approaches.
He's about to question the man when {1.SimFirstName} tugs on his hair and a mask pulls off his face, revealing the surly expression of a much younger man with blonde hair.

He's about to question the man when {1.SimFirstName} tugs on his hair and a mask pulls off his face, revealing the surly expression of a much younger man with blonde hair.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} throws the tablecloth on {1.SimFirstName}, who looks kind of sort of like a ghost dog. Still, it's better than nothing.
{1.SimFirstName} charges at the old man, but as {M1.he}{F1.she} starts to bark the cloth falls off, revealing the ordinary corporeal dog that {1.SimFirstName} is. The old man chuckles and turns back to the sea.
His expression changes a few seconds later, though, as the actual ghost dog floats inches from his face. He staggers backward, trips on {1.SimFirstName}, and falls with a thump onto the floor of the lookout.
{1.SimFirstName} takes the man's hair in his mouth as {0.SimFirstName} approaches. As {M0.he's}{F0.she's} about to question the man, {1.SimFirstName} tugs on his hair and a mask pulls off his face, revealing the surly expression of a much younger man with blonde hair.

String.Source: Use the Wood Glue to Trap the Old Man
String.Dest: Use the Wood Glue to Trap the Old Man

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} arrive at the lighthouse again, hoping to finally catch the alleged ghost.
The Private door is locked, so the two wind their way up to the top of the lighthouse. As they approach the top, {1.SimFirstName} calms {0.SimFirstName}, pointing out at the old man leaning on the railing.
The two hide behind a crate full of wood glue and tablecloths and listen to the man talking to himself. {0.SimFirstName} hears him cry something about his revenge being almost complete. Uh oh. That doesn't sound good.
Suddenly, something rises out of the crate in front of them, and it's all {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} can do to not shout. It's the ghost! The ethereal hound seems friendly though, and gestures at the crate, then at the old man. {0.SimFirstName} nods, knowing what to do.
String.Dest:
{0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} arrive at the lighthouse again, hoping to finally catch the alleged ghost.
The Private door is locked, so the two wind their way up to the top of the lighthouse. As they approach the top, {1.SimFirstName} calms {0.SimFirstName}, pointing out at the old man leaning on the railing.
The two hide behind a crate full of wood glue and tablecloths and listen to the man talking to himself. {0.SimFirstName} hears him cry something about his revenge being almost complete. Uh oh. That doesn't sound good.
Suddenly, something rises out of the crate in front of them, and it's all {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} can do to not shout. It's the ghost! The ethereal hound seems friendly though, and gestures at the crate, then at the old man. {0.SimFirstName} nods, knowing what to do.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} looks at the young man and suddenly recognizes him. "You're Charlie Crabcakes!" {M0.he}{F0.she} shouts. "Heir to the Crabcakes fortune."
"Yes," spits Charlie, "though not much of a fortune after the Brindleton Wreck where my dad's ship lost a year's supply of crabs! All because of that stupid Mr. Friendly and his sick dog." The ghost dog looks indignant and floats a few paces away.
"I was going to turn the lighthouse off, make the big fish shipment crash, and Brindleton Bay was sure to give crabs another chance! And I would have gotten away with it, too, if hadn't been for these two meddling dogs!"
"But...why the mask?" asks {0.SimFirstName}. Charlie wrenches himself away from {1.SimFirstName}, ditches his shoes, and hops to the edge of the lighthouse.
"I've got tons of masks!" he shouts, adding "and I'll get my revenge! You'll see." He jumps and {0.SimFirstName} gasps, but Charlie spreads his arms and he has some kind of glider jacket that catches the wind, as he disappears into the darkness of the water below.
It's not really an answer, and {0.SimFirstName} is still confused, but it seems that they've done their good deed for the moment and made a new ghostly friend. The ghost dog licks {0.SimFirstName}'s face - which, for the record, feels super weird but also comforting - then disappears down into the heart of the lighthouse.
{0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} head home, content.

String.Source:
The two head to the office. Inside, the ghost is lounging in the corner. It sees {0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} and jumps up in excitement.
The two dogs - one of this world, the other from beyond - skitter across the small office for a time, as {0.SimFirstName} reads some stories of Brindleton past.
After some time, the two head home, promising the ghost that they'll return again soon.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} find themselves back at the Brindleton Light.
The two look up at it, then at each other, remembering the odd adventure they had there not too long ago. "Come on," {0.SimFirstName} says to {1.SimFirstName}. "Let's go see if our dog pal from beyond is around."
The shop is empty today, though there are now a revolving group of volunteers who help run it. {1.SimFirstName} paws gently at the Private door, before walking over and looking up the regular stairs.
String.Dest:
{0.SimFirstName} and {1.SimFirstName} find themselves back at the Brindleton Light.
The two look up at it, then at each other, remembering the odd adventure they had there not too long ago. "Come on," {0.SimFirstName} says to {1.SimFirstName}. "Let's go see if our dog pal from beyond is around."
The shop is empty today, though there are now a revolving group of volunteers who help run it. {1.SimFirstName} paws gently at the Private door, before walking over and looking up the regular stairs.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} doesn't need {1.SimFirstName} to be drawn to the docks. Laughs from the regulars at the Salty Paws Saloon mix with the caws of gulls resting on the shoals. {0.SimFirstName} watches a group of them fly up and across the sails of boats docked at the harbor.
{0.SimFirstName} has {M0.his}{F0.her} pick of places to go.
String.Dest:
{0.SimFirstName} doesn't need {1.SimFirstName} to be drawn to the docks. Laughs from the regulars at the Salty Paws Saloon mix with the caws of gulls resting on the shoals. {0.SimFirstName} watches a group of them fly up and across the sails of boats docked at the harbor.
{0.SimFirstName} has {M0.his}{F0.her} pick of places to go.

String.Source:
{1.SimFirstName} takes the lead, dashing after the black figure, with {0.SimFirstName} not far behind. Salt-crusted wooden crates tower increasingly higher above them, until the horizon is lost. At the darkest corner, {1.SimFirstName} stops and turns {M1.his}{F1.her} head straight up. Above, a black cat with large yellow eyes is perched on the edge of the crate, watching them like a falcon. Is this what they've been chasing?
{0.SimFirstName} approaches carefully. {M0.He}{F0.She} inches forward, until {M0.he}{F0.she} is close enough to touch it. But {1.SimFirstName} cannot bear the anticipation any longer and barks in protest. The black cat disappears into the crates. {1.SimFirstName} keeps barking at the shadows, but {0.SimFirstName} knows it's gone. "Forget it {1.SimFirstName}, it's Whiskerman's Wharf."

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} looks down at {M0.his}{F0.her} dog, so eager to follow the figure into the crates. Together, they've run past the entire market tracking it down. "Is what we want really at the end of the trail?" ponders {0.SimFirstName}.
{0.SimFirstName} ends {M0.his}{F0.her} trip sitting on a patio of the Salty Paws Saloon overlooking the sea. Soon {0.SimFirstName}, the bartender and twelve bearded fishermen are singing sea shanties. {1.SimFirstName} howls along in tune.

String.Source:
As promised, they return to the pier. A regular at the Salty Paws Saloon recognizes {0.SimFirstName} and waves. He calls {0.SimFirstName} over. Meanwhile, {1.SimFirstName} has picked up {M1.his}{F1.her} trail. A dark blur dashes into towering crates at the unloading dock, and {1.SimFirstName} barks wildly after it.
Where should they go?

Where should they go?

String.Source:
The crowded marketplace is packed with sights and smells. But {1.SimFirstName} is interested in only one. {M1.He}{F1.She} darts between barrels of fish and over cobblestone streets in pursuit of the scent. {0.SimFirstName} just tries to keep up.
Finally, they stop on a balcony overlooking the sea. {1.SimFirstName}'s trail has gone cold. {0.SimFirstName} pats {1.SimFirstName}, trying to cheer {M1.him}{F1.her} up. Next time, they'll return.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} takes three ginger steps onto the deck and knocks on the door. "Who's there?" cries a voice from inside. {0.SimFirstName} takes a step back as the door opens to reveal an old woman with silvery hair swept up in a bun on her head. She's wearing horn-rimmed glasses and a long floral pink dress. "No solicitors!"
Before {0.SimFirstName} can respond, {1.SimFirstName} runs past both of them in through the cabin doors. "What's this!" she yells. "Get your animal off my skipper!" But just as quickly, {1.SimFirstName} comes running back out carrying a cardboard bag of what smells like fish. {M1.He}{F1.She} darts through the woman's legs, off the boat, and back up the harbor. {0.SimFirstName}'s dog has just committed robbery, so {M0.he}{F0.she} decides it's a good time to leave. As {1.SimFirstName} and {0.SimFirstName} head home, "My Trout!" echo in the distance.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} doesn't want to take any chances, and decides to look through the window first. {1.SimFirstName} is right at {M0.his}{F0.her} feet, and gets to the window first. On seeing what's inside, {1.SimFirstName}'s hairs raise and begins to growl. What could be inside? The cabin is so low that {0.SimFirstName} has to bend down to get a look.
Two green eyes and a set of whiskers are staring back at {0.SimFirstName}. A cat wearing a sailor's hat is standing with two hind legs on the driver's seat and two paws on the helm. It blinks, staring at {0.SimFirstName} blankly.
Outside, {0.SimFirstName} hears the propeller start and the boat begins to back away from the dock. Tearing {1.SimFirstName} away from the absurd scene, they both get off the boat. It sails away, cruising into the horizon.

String.Source:
They return to the harbor, and pick up the trail where {1.SimFirstName} left it. Only this time, there's something there.
{0.SimFirstName} walks them down the harbor to the last boat on the dock. It is a tiny blue and white skipper with "Old Lady Sea" written in black across the bow. A tiny door to the cabin is just across the deck, as is a small window. Knocking would be polite, but taking a peak through the window might give {0.SimFirstName} more of an idea what {1.SimFirstName} was chasing after.

String.Source:
{1.SimFirstName} leads them on a trail down the windswept hills into the wide open harbor of Whiskerman's Wharf. Schooners and skippers docked in soft rows bob gently with the tide. {0.SimFirstName} admires the scene, but {1.SimFirstName}'s nose is to the ground. {M1.His}{F1.Her} focus is entirely on the fresh scent of a trail. {0.SimFirstName} follows {1.SimPronounObjective} through the docks.
Finally, {1.SimFirstName} stops at a wooden dock, but whatever boat was there is gone. The trail's gone cold. {0.SimFirstName} promises they'll return next time.

String.Source:
There's no telling what sharp rocks lies beneath the dark water's surface, and {0.SimFirstName} just isn't willing to take that chance. Time slows down as {0.SimFirstName} launches forward and grabs {1.SimFirstName} around the middle just as {M1.he}{F1.she} is mid leap. It is an act of gravity-defying athleticism that you'd have to see to believe.
{0.SimFirstName} is sure to spend the rest of the week reliving how {M0.he}{F0.she} saved {M0.his}{F0.her} dog from the rocky depths in a mid-air rescue. {0.SimFirstName} returns home with a confidence boost.

String.Source:
{0.SimFirstName} recoils from the large splash after {1.SimFirstName} makes the jump. As {M0.he}{F0.she} rubs salt water from {M0.his}{F0.her} eyes, {0.SimFirstName} bends over the rock to try and locate {M0.his}{F0.her} adventurous animal, who has disappeared beneath the water. {1.SimFirstName} is nowhere to be seen.
Desperately, {0.SimFirstName} scans the water's surface. A dark blur moves just a few feet in front of {0.SimPronounObjective}. {M0.He}{F0.She} sighs in relief as it makes its way towards {0.SimPronounObjective}. {M0.He}{F0.She} reaches out {M0.his}{F0.her} hand to help {1.SimFirstName} back up, but instantly draws it back when a furless, wire-whiskered head appears in {1.SimFirstName}'s place. It's a sea lion!
{1.SimFirstName} pops {M1.his}{F1.her} head out of the water soon after. It appears the two have an accord. {0.SimFirstName} helps {1.SimFirstName} back up the shoals, and they say goodbye to their friend for today.

String.Source: On {0.SimFirstName}’s ok, {1.SimFirstName} takes off. The path looks to be going to the old Brindleton Bay Lighthouse. "I’m sure it’s just superstition," {0.SimFirstName} thinks.
